entry.title: A Post Quantum Migration Proposal
entry.summary:
The concern raised addresses the potential vulnerabilities and counterproductive nature of a proposed method to secure Unspent Transaction Outputs (UTXOs) in the face of quantum computing advancements. The method in question, which aims to protect UTXOs by preventing their movement to quantum-safe addresses and relying on proof-of-work (PoW) lock mechanisms, is critiqued for potentially exacerbating security issues rather than mitigating them. The critique highlights that this approach could inadvertently prioritize the cracking of these PoW-locked coins over the traditional role of miners in securing the network through block discovery. This shift in focus might not only reduce the incentive for conventional mining activities but also disproportionately benefit miners with significant hashrate capabilities, essentially turning what was intended as a protective measure into a lucrative opportunity for a select few at the expense of the broader user base's security.
Furthermore, the method is scrutinized for giving the Cryptographically Relevant Quantum Computer (CRQC) additional time to break exposed public keys, thereby undermining the very objective of enhancing security against quantum computing threats. This strategy is perceived as detrimental, not just for failing to adequately safeguard against quantum vulnerabilities, but also for potentially diverting resources and focus away from more effective security measures. Such an approach could lead to an uneven distribution of rewards, skewed towards miners with substantial hashrate, thereby disincentivizing the fundamental aspect of mining that contributes to the network's overall security. The critique implicitly calls for a reassessment of strategies aimed at protecting against quantum computing risks, emphasizing the need for solutions that reinforce rather than compromise network security and equitable participation.
